occurrences.line_text: O why should heauenly God to man haue such regard?
The charge, which God doth vnto me arret,
So streightly God doth iudge. But gentle knight,
And said; Faire Son, great God thy right hand blesse,
Certes (then said the Prince) I God auow,
That God hath built for his owne blessed bowre.
We needes must passe (God do vs well acquight,)
Therefore a God him sage Antiquity
That blinded God, which hath ye blindly smit,
But neither God of loue, nor God of sky
But neither God of loue, nor God of sky
Well did Antiquitie a God thee deeme,
Thou God of winds, that raignest in the seas,
The God did graunt his daughters deare demaund,
The prayses of high God he faire displayes,
Ah dearest God (quoth he) that is great woe,
Now God thee keepe, thou gentlest Squire aliue,
Ah God, what other could he do at least,
And doth not highest God vouchsafe to take
Eternall God in his almighty powre,
Her little sonne, the winged god of loue,
With which high God his workmanship hath deckt;
To search the God of loue, her Nymphes she sent
It fortuned (high God did so ordaine)
For which to God he made so many an idle boone.
And with blasphemous bannes high God in peeces tare.
So much high God doth innocence embrace.
Sometimes he boasted, that a God he hight:
And but God turne the same to good soothsay,
The God of his desire, the ioy of misers blind.
And loathsome life, of God and man abhord,
Battell against the Gods? so we a God inuade.
Whenas the God to golden hew him selfe transfard.
The God himselfe rending his golden heare,
The God himselfe did pensiue seeme and sad,
So proou'd it eke that gracious God of wine,
Next after her the winged God himselfe
And wicked wordes that God and man offended:
The God of loue, with wings displayed wide,
Vntrue to God, and vnto man vniust,
None but a God or godlike man can slake;
This now be yours, God send you better gaine.
The God of warre, she from her middle loosd,
Great God of loue, that with thy cruell darts,
A wofull wretched maid, of God and man forgot.
And that which wont to vanquish God and man,
And curse his God, that did him so confound;
Praysing their god, and yeelding him great thankes,
Great God of men and women, queene of th'ayre,
Both gifts of God not gotten but from thence,
A God of seas through his mad mothers blame,
Like a wood God, and flowing fast to Rhy:
That if old sawes proue true (which God forbid)
Yet had refusde a God that her had sought to wife.
To whom God Neptune softly smyling, thus;
Resembling God in his imperiall might;
Now by my life (sayd he) and God to guide,
High God, whose goodnesse he despaired quight,
Or God or Fortune vnto me did throw,
That Iustice was a God of soueraine grace,
So blesse thee God, and giue thee ioyance of thy dreame
But makes his God of his vngodly pelfe,
But thankt be God, and your good hardiment,
Hymnes to high God, and carols heauenly things,
With which high God had blest her happie land,
And she take comfort, which God now did send:
To God, to doe vnto his Idole most vntrew.
He hath set vp, and him his God hath named;
The more t'aggrate his God with such his blouddy guize.
Whom neither dread of God, that deuils bindes,
Now God you speed (quoth then Sir Artegall)
They tooke it well, and thanked God for all,
Stay stay, Sir Knight, for loue of God abstaine,
The which the God of loue hath on me layd,
For loe the winged God, that woundeth harts,
Certes (sayd then the Prince) the God is iust,
That since by grace of God she there was sent,
Vnto their God they would her sacrifize,
They prayd high God him farre from them to send.
Therefore the winged God, to let men weet,
So forth they goe together (God before)
The same is yonder Lady, whom high God did saue.
And with them eke, O Goddesse heauenly bright,
And worship her as Goddesse of the wood;
The goddesse wroth gan fowly her disgrace,
Faire Goddesse lay that furious fit aside,
The goddesse heard, and suddeine where she sate,
O Goddesse, (for such I thee take to bee)
The Goddesse pleased with his wanton play,
Sith of that Goddesse I haue sought the sight,
Or as the Cyprian goddesse, newly borne
And by his side the Goddesse groueling
Calles thee, his goddesse in his error blind,
Angell, or Goddesse do I call thee right?
Nor Goddesse I, nor Angell, but the Mayd,
Whereas she found the Goddesse with her crew,
Well as she might, and to the Goddesse rose,
Ioying his goddesse, and of her enioyd:
But or some Goddesse, or of Dianes crew,
Weening some heauenly goddesse he did see,
Right in the midst the Goddesse selfe did stand
Thee goddesse, thee the winds, the clouds doe feare,
For ill your goddesse seruices are drest
And euermore vpon the Goddesse face
Dread Souerayne Goddesse, that doest highest sit
A Goddesse of great powre and souerainty
Such was the Goddesse; whom when Britomart
But that the Goddesse with her rod him backe did beat.
She for a present to their Goddesse brought.
That all they as a Goddesse her adoring,
Did for their soueraine goddesse her esteeme,
Whether a creature, or a goddesse graced
For which the three faire Goddesses did striue:
Sweete Goddesses all three which me in mirth do cherry.
Such were those Goddesses, which ye did see;
Mammon (said he) thy godheades vaunt is vaine,
And write the battels of his great godhed:
None but a God or godlike man can slake;
So with that godly father to his home they went.
And all the day in doing good and godly deedes.
In goodly thewes, and godly exercise:
The godly Matrone by the hand him beares
Did spend their dayes in doing godly thing:
And godly worke of Almes and charitee
There they do finde that godly aged Sire,
That I this man of God his godly armes may blaze.
That godly King and Queene did passionate,
Where euer he that godly knight may find,
Who in all godly thewes, and goodly prayse
With which he godly Oswald shall subdew,
Great Godmer threw, in fierce contention,
The Gods stand gazing on, when she does ride
Or that great house of Gods cï¿½lestiall,
O what of Gods then boots it to be borne,
That to the house of heauenly gods it raught,
For Gods deare loue, Sir knight, do me not stay;
For death was due to him, that had prouokt Gods ire.
But all the good is Gods, both power and eke will.
That drew on men Gods hatred, and his wrath,
Those for Gods sake his dewty was to entertaine.
The wondrous workemanship of Gods owne mould,
For Gods deare loue be not so wilfull bent,
Which doe the temple of the Gods support,
To weet, which of the Gods I shall thee name,
From whence the gods haue her for enuy thrust:
The which emongst the gods false Ate threw;
Accusing highest Ioue and gods ingrate,
Cursing his Gods, and himselfe damning deepe:
Of all Gods workes, which do this world adorne,
That all the Gods admird his loftie note.
Or Ida, where the Gods lou'd to repaire,
In which the Gods do dwell eternally:
For Tryphon of sea gods the soueraine leach is hight.
Of all the Gods) where thou vngratious,
Of gods high prayse, and of their loues sweet teene,
Such as the Angels weare before Gods tribunall.
The Gods doe dread, he dearely shall abye:
Yet pittie often did the gods relent,
Of Stygian Gods, which doe her loue enuy;
With many of the Gods in company,
Pleasure, that doth both gods and men aggrate,
Before that angry Gods, and cruell skye
Battell against the Gods? so we a God inuade.
Gainst all the Gods, to make his empire great;
Vnto the Victor of the Gods this bee:
Farre from the view of Gods and heauens blis,
Not all the gods can chaunge, nor Ioue him self can free.
As one in feare the Stygian gods t'offend,
Deuized by the Gods, for to asswage
Are by the Gods to drinck thereof assynd;
And there made gods, though borne of mortall berth,
Before that they in blisse amongst the Gods were plaste.
That all the gods did mone her miserable case.
To all the heathen Gods, might like to this be clamed.
The ioy of Gods and men, that vnder skie
Old Styx the Grandame of the Gods, doth lay.
Should for the Gods in Proteus house be made;
To that great banquet of the watry Gods,
And could the ledden of the Gods vnfold,
Like as the mother of the Gods, they say,
Of Gods, of Nymphs, of riuers yet vnred:
The manner of the Gods when they at banquet bee.
Ne with th'eternall Gods to bancket come;
Ye Gods of seas, if any Gods at all
Ye Gods of seas, if any Gods at all
But leauing watry gods, as booting nought,
And place deserued with the Gods on hy.
With which the Gods themselues are mylder made:
But by Gods grace, and her good heedinesse,
That Gods and men doe equally adore,
To his inferiour Gods, and euermore
Wroth with the Gods, which to perpetuall paine
To make new warre against the Gods againe:
Can from th'immortall Gods ought hidden bee?
High Gods beheast, and powre of holy lawes;
The flesh of men, to Gods owne likenesse framed,
Against his Gods, and fire to them did threat,
A dreadfull feend of gods and men ydrad,
Since it at first was by the Gods with paine
For loue amongst the woodie Gods to dwell;)
To Gods sole grace, whom she did oft implore,
Here by the Gods, and fed with heauenly sap,
Whom Gods doe hate, and heauens abhor to see;
To her the Gods, for her so dreadfull face,
What could the Gods doe more, but doe it more aright?
But loe the Gods, that mortall follies vew,
Vow'd to the gods: religio[n] held euen theeues in measure.
his cure to hell does goe.
Goe caytiue Elfe, him quickly ouertake,
Goe guiltie ghost, to him my message make,
And to him said, Goe now proud Miscreant,
Goe say, his foe thy shield with his doth beare.
Or else goe them auenge, and let be seene,
Goe to then, O thou farre renowmed sonne
To her yeeld passage, gainst his Lord to goe,
They let her goe at will, and wander wayes vnknowne.
The further he doth goe, the further he doth stray.
Then do no further goe, no further stray,
To come, and goe with tydings from the hart,
The eldest did against the youngest goe,
To trauell, goe to see that dreadfull place:
And sharply said; Goe Dame, goe seeke your boy,
And sharply said; Goe Dame, goe seeke your boy,
They bene agreed, and to the gates they goe
And euer faine he towards them would goe,
Those feeling wordes so neare the quicke did goe,
Or warded, or auoyded and let goe,
Or creepe betweene his legs, so in to goe,
Sometime with tender teares to let her goe,
But vnto great king Neptune selfe did goe,
And into nothing goe, ere one could it bewray.
Goe damzell quickly, doe thy selfe addresse,
Goe thou vnto that stranger Faery Knight,
Goe streight, and take with thee, to witnesse it,
Goe now, Clarinda, well thy wits aduise,
Thus goe they both together to their geare,
Yet could the Prince not nigh vnto him goe,
Agree to goe with her, and by the way,
Ay me (sayd she) and whether shall I goe?
Nathlesse (said he) deare Ladie with me goe,
The trompets sound, and they together goe,
Would thumpe her forward, and inforce to goe,
Chyld Tristram prayd, that he with him might goe
To goe about to salue such kynd of sore,
That good should from vs goe, then come in greater store.
So forth they goe together (God before)
In which the great Goemagot of strong
He to his study goes, and there amiddes
But to the wood she goes, to serue her turne,
The light goes out, and weeke is throwne away;
Full fast she flies, and farre afore him goes,
He where he list goes loose, and laughes at me.
She goes to seeke him, Dolon meetes
Wherewith he goeth to that soueraine Queene,
But some doe say, it goeth downe to hell.
But rather y Scuith gogh, signe of sad crueltee.
Purfled with gold and pearle of rich assay,
Ne spared he to giue her gold and rings:
In glistring gold, and peerelesse pretious stone:
Adorned all with gold, and girlonds gay,
Vpon a Camell loaden all with gold;
Those heapes of gold with griple Couetyse,
Adornd with gold and iewels shining cleare,
And gorgeous gold arayd I to thee came;
He gaue her gold and purple pall to weare,
Whose hilts were burnisht gold, and handle strong
His haughtie helmet, horrid all with gold,
With sprincled pearle, and gold full richly drest,
Which hong adowne his side in twisted gold,
With royall arras and resplendent gold.
Embowd with gold and gorgeous ornament,
But nor for gold nor glee will I abide
And in her right hand bore a cup of gold,
And on her head she wore a tyre of gold,
In their defence, nor would for gold or fee
With princely gifts of yuorie and gold,
With silken curtens and gold couerlets,
Was vnderneath enueloped with gold,
Great heapes of gold, that neuer could be spent:
Fountaines of gold and siluer to abound,
Thy workes for wealth, and life for gold engage.
Or where hast thou thy wonne, that so much gold
Embost with massy gold of glorious gift,
Both roofe, and floore, and wals were all of gold,
To a broad gate, all built of beaten gold:
She held a great gold chaine ylincked well,
And planted there, did bring forth fruit of gold:
Why takest not of that same fruit of gold,
Yet gold all is not, that doth golden seeme,
Braunched with gold & pearle, most richly wrought,
In a long purple pall, whose skirt with gold,
Therefore he first wore crowne of gold for dignitie.
And otherwhiles with gold besprinkeled;
And them amongst, some were of burnisht gold,
In her left hand a Cup of gold she held,
And ouer all, of purest gold was spred,
Her garments all were wrought of beaten gold,
That glistred all with gold and glorious shew,
That was with gold and Ermines faire enueloped.
And round about yfretted all with gold,
That fame in trompe of gold eternally displayes.
All fretted round with gold, and goodly well beseene.
For gold, or perles, or pretious stones an howre,
Gold, amber, yuorie, perles, owches, rings,
Royally clad (quoth he) in cloth of gold,
The one of yron, the other of bright gold,
That loues his fetters, though they were of gold.
Wouen with gold and silke so close and nere,
And flame with gold, but the white fomy creame,
Of massy gold, which with his owne light shone;
Some headed with sad lead, some with pure gold;
But with pure gold it all was ouerlayd,
And her faire lockes were wouen vp in gold;
Without adorne of gold or siluer bright,
With gold and many a gorgeous ornament,
Of gold, that bad eyes might it not prophane:
Vnto the vulgar for good gold insted,
No lesse then perfect gold surmounts the meanest brasse.
Enwouen was with gold, that raught full low a downe.
Nor shining gold, nor mouldring clay it was;
With nimble wings of gold and purple hew;
Yet quaile in conquest of that land of gold.
And garnisht all with gold vpon the blade
Whilest he to gathering of the gold did fall.
Vnder an heape of gold. Thence he her drew
But he her suppliant hands, those hands of gold,
Basted with bends of gold on euery side,
His Lyons skin chaungd to a pall of gold,
With shining gold, and arched ouer hed,
Vppon her head she wore a Crowne of gold,
And Moone-like Mitre to a Crowne of gold,
And royall gifts of gold and siluer wrought,
And all their tops bright glistering with gold,
Vpon a throne of gold full bright and sheene,
Not of rich tissew, nor of cloth of gold,
Glistring like gold, amongst the plights enrold,
There he that Idoll saw of massy gold
For guiftes of gold, or any worldly glee,
Dearer is loue then life, and fame then gold;
The wisest sight, to thinke gold that is bras.
Pinckt vpon gold, and paled part per part,
So forth he drew much gold, and toward him it driue.
They did esteeme, and offred store of gold.
Whose bridle rung with golden bels and bosses braue.
For golden Phoebus now ymounted hie,
And golden foile all ouer them displaid,
Great Iunoes golden chaire, the which they say
At last the golden Orientall gate
Of mother pearle, and buckled with a golden tong.
His golden wings: his dreadfull hideous hed
That Phoebus golden face it did attaint,
And Gehons golden waues doe wash continually.
Then tooke the angrie witch her golden cup,
Her golden cup she cast vnto the ground,
O Goodly golden chaine, wherewith yfere
The golden Sunne his glistring head gan shew,
Was writ with golden letters rich and braue;
Her guiltlesse garments, and her golden heare,
Now gan the golden Phoebus for to steepe
Her golden lockes for haste were loosely shed
Her looser golden lockes he rudely rent,
Her golden lockes most cruelly she rent,
But temperance (said he) with golden squire
the face of golden Meane.
He left his loftie steed with golden sell,
Her golden lockes she roundly did vptye
That rode in golden sell with single spere,
With golden aygulets, that glistred bright,
Was hemd with golden fringe
All bard with golden bendes, which were entayld
Knit with a golden bauldricke, which forelay
Her yellow lockes crisped, like golden wyre,
And idle offers of thy golden fee;
To melt the golden metall, ready to be tride.
But he himselfe was all of golden mould,
Many great golden pillours did vpbeare
Their fruit were golden apples glistring bright,
Here also sprong that goodly golden fruit,
Here eke that famous golden Apple grew,
How oft do they with golden pineons, cleaue
His snowy front curled with golden heares,
Yet gold all is not, that doth golden seeme,
That seruice well. Her yellow golden heare
But Elfiline enclosd it with a golden wall.
His goodly conquest of the golden fleece,
And th'yuorie in golden mantle gownd:
That bore a Lion passant in a golden field.
And with that golden chaine of concord tyde.
To crowne his golden lockes with honour dew;
And all the grauell mixt with golden owre;
So long that now the golden Hesperus
Her golden lockes, that late in tresses bright
With golden wreath and gorgeous ornament;
Besides her golden girdle, which did fall
The golden ribband, which that virgin wore
With golden wyre to weaue her curled head;
Yet golden wyre was not so yellow thrise
I found her golden girdle cast astray,
Her golden locks, that were in tramels gay
Their vapour vaded, shew their golden gleames,
Was inly tickled with that golden vew,
But weete henceforth, that all that golden pray,
Till drouping Phoebus gan to hide his golden hed.
Soone after that into a golden showre
Whenas the God to golden hew him selfe transfard.
The God himselfe rending his golden heare,
Ease, on his robe in golden letters cyphered.
Which doft, her golden lockes, that were vp bound
The golden Apple, cause of all their wrong,
All mindlesse of the Golden fleece, which made them striue.
And that great golden chaine quite to diuide,
With golden words, and goodly countenance,
Shall haue that golden girdle for reward,
Yet all was forg'd and spred with golden foyle,
Combing her golden lockes, as seemd her good:
Her golden cup to them for drinke she raught,
Him needeth sure a golden pen I weene,
With golden foyle doth finely ouer spred
Then was that golden belt by doome of all
Like to a golden border did appeare,
For it did glister like the golden sand,
And with a litle golden chaine about it bound.
Was hangd on high with golden ribbands laced;
With golden letters goodly well enchaced,
Pactolus glistring with his golden flood,
That it encompast round as with a golden fret.
For from the golden age, that first was named,
For that same golden fleecy Ram, which bore
With golden hands and siluer feete beside,
Which bore the Sunne brode blazed in a golden field.
But Artegall that golden belt vptooke,
And th'one hand seizing on his golden bit,
As he with golden saddle is arayd;
And wrapt in fetters of a golden tresse,
With golden giftes and many a guilefull word
Downe on his golden feete he often gazed,
And rends her golden locks, and snowy brests embrew.
You well reward, and golden guerdon giue,
What time the golden apple was vnto him brought.
As yet not laced, nor her golden haire
Sweet Loue, that doth his golding wings embay
As guilefull Goldsmith that by secret skill,
Framed in goldsmithes forge with cunning hand:
Yet goldsmithes cunning could not vnderstand
For all so soone, as Guyon thence was gon
As glad of that small rest, as Bird of tempest gon.
I put repentaunce for things past and gon.
Although his quest were farre afore him gon;
A litle Gondelay, bedecked trim
There her small Gondelay her port did make,
Into her mouth they crept, and suddain all were gone.
Dead sculs & bones of men, whose life had gone astray.
For sorrowes past; their griefe is with them gone:
So on a day when Satyres all were gone,
And zealous hast away is quickly gone
Sith his good steed is lately from him gone;
Sometimes she laught, that nigh her breth was gone,
But when she saw them gone, she forward went,
Taketh his nimble wings, and soone away is gone.
The word gone out, she backe againe would call,
After she had nine moneths fulfild and gone:
That their faire guest was gone, they both begonne
To find him forth: and after her are gone
It fortuned, soone after they were gone,
So bene they gone yfeare, a wanton paire
And take me for their Ioue, whiles Ioue to earth is gone.
But when as she her selfe was lost and gone,
That was the Saluage Knight: but he was gone
That she was gone, departed thence with speed,
But thought she wandred was, or gone astray.
Equall to this, where euer I haue gone.
When I was gone, soone after me she sent
He could aduance, he farre was gone and past.
Ne none can backe returne, that once are gone amis.
But sith that he is gone irreuocable,
And cleane were gone, which way he neuer knew;
For being gone, none can them bring in place,
Sith they that were the cause of all, were gone.
The eldest Gonorill gan to protest,
With Gonorill, long had in great renowne,
At that good knight so cunningly didst roue,
The Aspine good for staues, the Cypresse funerall.
Making her death their life, and eke her hurt their good.
Of that good knight, his late beguiled guest:
But this good knight soone as he them can spie,
And knew well all was true. But the good knight
Which giuen was to them for good intents;
Good cause of mine excuse; that mote ye please
That hope of new good hap he gan to feele;
Ne scarse good morsell all his life did tast,
For death it was, when any good he saw,
He hated all good workes and vertuous deeds,
So euery good to bad he doth abuse:
But that good knight would not so nigh repaire,
And good successes, which their foes ensew:
Good cause he had to hasten thence away;
That good knight of the Redcrosse to haue slain:
At last she chaunced by good hap to meet
And said; faire Sir, I hope good hap hath brought
It was my chance (my chance was faire and good)
